content.description: A massive 16 billion record data breach exposing Apple, Google, and Facebook login credentials ranks among the largest in history.
Olive Garden’s parent company stock hit a record high before dipping, driven by the chain’s strongest sales growth in over two years.
Banks are promoting home-equity lines of credit as a cheaper borrowing option amid expected rate cuts and a broader slowdown in home sales.

Walmart removed all self-checkout machines from a Missouri store after police data showed theft-related calls significantly declined following their removal. This could signal a broader shift among major retailers away from self-checkout systems.
Citi believes the Israeli-Iranian conflict will be short-term, and the S&P500 will remain resilient as in past conflicts.

outlook: Markets may remain stable despite geopolitical tensions, with the S&P500 expected to ride through short-term shocks. Retail trends suggest a shift in operational strategies as companies prioritize shrink reduction over automation. Strong restaurant earnings hint at consumer resilience in discretionary spending, while the housing market signals a pivot toward alternative financing amid cooling demand. The massive data breach could trigger short-term volatility in tech stocks due to trust concerns but is unlikely to derail long-term momentum.
